science.headline: Cells Use ‘Bioelectricity’ To Coordinate and Make Group Decisions
science.teaser: The discovery that tissues use electricity to expel unhealthy cells is part of a surge of renewed interest in the currents flowing through our bodies. The post Cells Use ‘Bioelectricity’ To Coordinate and Make Group Decisions first appeared on Quanta Magazine
science.tldr: Reveals how our bodies are using electricity in unexpected ways

science.headline: String Theory Can Now Describe a Universe That Has Dark Energy
science.teaser: In an unprecedented step, researchers crafted a detailed model compatible with the universe’s accelerated expansion. The post String Theory Can Now Describe a Universe That Has Dark Energy first appeared on Quanta Magazine
science.tldr: Researchers now have a model compatible with dark energy's expansion

science.headline: Why There’s No Single Best Way To Store Information
science.teaser: The math of data structures helps us understand how different storage systems come with different trade-offs between resources such as time and memory. The post Why There’s No Single Best Way To Store Information first appeared on Quanta Magazine
science.tldr: Analyzes trade-offs between time and memory in data storage systems

philosophy.headline: Landholder vs stockholder
philosophy.teaser: In 1752, David Hume discerned that wealth was becoming untethered from land. Here lies the origin of our political divisions - by Catherine Nichols Read on Aeon
philosophy.tldr: Recognizes that shifts in wealth distribution fundamentally alters societal power

philosophy.headline: The synthetic self
philosophy.teaser: In order to better understand our human nature, we must attempt to build a robot capable of robust subjective experiences - by Tony J Prescott Read on Aeon
philosophy.tldr: Analyzes human nature by creating a robot capable of subjective experiences

philosophy.headline: How to become a tree
philosophy.teaser: Many people today want to commit their remains to rejuvenating the planet. But are these green deaths just greenwashing? - by Hannah Gould & Georgina Robinson Read on Aeon
philosophy.tldr: Challenges conventional views on death and its environmental impact

society.headline: The Mythology Of Conscious AI
society.teaser: The post The Mythology Of Conscious AI appeared first on NOEMA .
society.tldr: Challenges our understanding of human consciousness and its relation to AI

society.headline: The Politics Of Planetary Color
society.teaser: The post The Politics Of Planetary Color appeared first on NOEMA .
society.tldr: Reveals the politics behind how planetary color affects human perception

society.headline: How The ‘AI Job Shock’ Will Differ From The ‘China Trade Shock’
society.teaser: The post How The ‘AI Job Shock’ Will Differ From The ‘China Trade Shock’ appeared first on NOEMA .
society.tldr: Challenges the notion that automation will disproportionately harm low-skilled workers

books.headline: The Millions’ Great Winter 2026 Preview
books.teaser: Winter demands that we slow down, take stock, rest. And while we hibernate, books can keep us company. Luckily, this season, there are plenty of noteworthy new reads to fill these cold, short days. Below, you’ll find 100 titles out this winter that we’re excited about here at The Millions. Some we’v
books.tldr: Highlights the importance of slowing down to appreciate great winter reads

books.headline: At the Edge of Erasure: An Interview with Anouche Kunth, Historian of Exile
books.teaser: In the basement of a French administration office there was a mass of 12,000 documents related to the refugees of the Armenian genocide, telling a terse story of loss. The post At the Edge of Erasure: An Interview with Anouche Kunth, Historian of Exile appeared first on Public Books .
books.tldr: Discovers a significant cache of documents shedding light on Armenian genocide

books.headline: Against Babel: Or, How to Talk to Strangers
books.teaser: Allegedly, some 45% of languages descend from one, ancient ”Proto-Indo-European“ tongue. But why focus on a hypothetical lost language, when we can work instead to hear one another today? The post Against Babel: Or, How to Talk to Strangers appeared first on Public Books .
books.tldr: Discovers why understanding common ancestry can bridge linguistic divides effectively

essays.headline: At Least My Best Friend Stabbed Me in the Front
essays.teaser: “Slut Lullabies” by Gina Frangello I found out my mother was a slut from my best friend, at a bar with my secret Greek boyfriend who was possibly a homosexual and his uptight brother who pretended to know nothing of our affair. I was high on myself that evening. It was a buzz I got […] The post At L
essays.tldr: Reveals painful truth about author's friend and family dynamics

essays.headline: Surviving My Assault Means Understanding Where, and Who, I Come From
essays.teaser: Editor’s note: This essay deals with topics of childhood sexual assault, rape, and incest. “Hush” by Torie Rose Wiley The Armless Maiden, or in some retellings, The Maiden Without Hands, is an ancient folktale that has been passed down throughout different cultures and generations. In the older vers
essays.tldr: Speaks truth about trauma and healing for survivors of childhood assault

essays.headline: A Mother-Daughter Novel That Transforms the Western
essays.teaser: “Go West, young man!”—a phrase that looms large in the United States’s history of westward expansion. It’s a history dominated by the displacement of Indigenous peoples, the exploitation and destruction of land, and a drive to claim more, more, always more: more resources, more gold, and more land,
essays.tldr: Reveals painful truths about America's colonial past
